item.title: Why WoW Subscription Prices Have Never Gone Up--"It's A Prickly Audience"
item.content:encoded:
https://www.gamespot.com/articles/why-wow-subscription-prices-have-never-gone-up-its-a-prickly-audience/1100-6529525/?ftag=CAD-01-10abi2f

GameSpot may receive revenue from affiliate and advertising partnerships for sharing this content and from purchases through links.

World of Warcraft has required a $15 monthly subscription to play since its launch back in 2004, but in all those years, the price in the US has never gone up. According to ex-Activision Blizzard CEO Bobby Kotick, it was due to not wanting to "agitate" the game's playerbase.

In an interview with the Grit podcast, Kotick reflected on his long history as the CEO of Activision and later Activision Blizzard. Along the way he dove into details about developer Blizzard and WoW's success.

He said the game over its lifetime has seen over 150 million subscribers, making it the "best subscription business of all time." When one of the interviewers suggested the price of the subscription could have been "priced more highly" given WoW's huge success, Kotick pushed back against the idea.

"We never raised the price," Kotick said. "My view was we come up with value-added services, come up with new things to sell, but just leave the price. We could figure out how to come up with other things to sell them. And it's a prickly audience, you know? You don't wanna do too much to agitate them. And even a dollar increase would've been a problem in my view."

Kotick went on to talk about how vital Blizzard veteran Chris Metzen was to the company's success, and said he was, and still is, "the soul of creativity at the company." Metzen retired from Blizzard in 2016 (according to Kotick, due to burnout related to the Warcraft movie) but returned in 2022 as a creative advisor on WoW. He is now an executive creative director for the Warcraft universe. Prior to returning to Blizzard, Kotick said Metzen believed WoW's upcoming expansions were in bad shape, and Kotick "begged him" to return in order to fix them.

"Just come do it, you're the guy, come do it," Kotick said he told Metzen.

Kotick said Metzen had his "fingerprints" all over the MMORPG's latest expansion, The War Within, and that the next expansion, under Metzen's guidance, "is going to be great." Once Metzen returned to Blizzard, Kotick said he hardly ever talked with him, instead preferring to let him get to work.

"What am I going to tell Chris Metzen about game design?" Kotick said. "I just wanted him to do his thing."

Kotick served as CEO of Activision, and later Activision Blizzard, from 1991-2023, stepping down after the publisher's sale to Microsoft for $69 billion, which came after a variety of controversies involving the publisher.

item.title: Almost Half Of Steam Users Still Use Windows 10, Despite Impending End Of Life
item.content:encoded:
https://www.gamespot.com/articles/almost-half-of-steam-users-still-use-windows-10-despite-impending-end-of-life/1100-6529522/?ftag=CAD-01-10abi2f

GameSpot may receive revenue from affiliate and advertising partnerships for sharing this content and from purchases through links.

Windows 11 has been here for a while, but that doesn't mean that Windows 10 users are willing to go gentle into that good night, despite its impending "end-of-life" date of October 14, 2025. As spotted by PC Guide, according to Steam's January 2025 Hardware & Software Survey, more than 44% of the storefront's users are still on Windows 10, with more than 55% opting for Windows 11.

Windows 11 has been out for four years now, but there are a few obvious reasons for its lack of market penetration. For one, the differences between Windows 10 and Windows 11 can be difficult to suss out at a first glance, and for most users, there isn't really a strong reason to upgrade. For another, Windows 11 came along with some stiff hardware requirements that essentially locked out those with older processors, even though many of those machines can still run many PCs games well.

Windows 10's end of life means that Microsoft will no longer receive software updates or security fixes, and the company has been encouraging users to upgrade for years now. It seems inevitable that the numbers will begin to shift a bit more, a process that has perhaps already started--Windows 10 had a slight majority of Steam's userbase in September of last year, losing roughly 5% in the interim. The survey also revealed that the most popular GPU for Steam users is the Nvidia GeForce RTX 3060, that 16 GB RAM is the most common, and that a majority of Steam users have hard drives with more than 1 TB total space and 100 to 249 GB of free space. item.title: Shinobi: Art of Vengeance PC Preorder Discount At Fanatical
item.content:encoded:
https://www.gamespot.com/articles/shinobi-art-of-vengeance-pc-preorder-discount-at-fanatical/1100-6529514/?ftag=CAD-01-10abi2f

GameSpot may receive revenue from affiliate and advertising partnerships for sharing this content and from purchases through links.

Shinobi: Art of Vengeance is scheduled to release on August 29, and PC preorders are currently seeing a nice discount at Fanatical. Head over to the online retailer to find the Steam version of the game on sale for $23.69 (was $30). If you want some digital goodies, the Deluxe Edition is also on sale for $31.59 (was $40). Regardless of which version you preorder, you’ll get the Original Arcade Outfit and Fortune Hunter Amulet as a bonus. You'll also get a 5% off voucher for your next purchase at Fanatical.

Created by the same folks responsible for the fantastic Streets of Rage 4, Shinobi: Art of Vengeance is shaping up to be a welcome revival for the 2D action game. Featuring bold hand-drawn graphics and taking deep inspiration from The Revenge of Shinobi and Shinobi 3, it’s a fresh blend of nostalgia and new mechanics. Art of Vengeance marks the first Shinobi game from Sega in over a decade.

This is the best discount we’ve seen since it was opened for preorder a few days ago, and since it comes with a nice preorder bonus and is offered as a Steam key, it’s the ideal way for PC players to snag the game. Note that Steam is also discounting the game right now, but it’s still more expensive than this deal at Fanatical.

The standard version includes just the base game and preorder bonus, but the Digital Deluxe Edition is packed with extras. This includes early access on August 26 along with the following:

Shinobi: Art of Vengeance Digital Deluxe Edition

  • Starter Pack: Ghost Outfit, Medic Lite Amulet, In-Game Currency
  • SEGA Villains Stage (Coming Early 2026)
  • Digital Art Book
  • Digital Soundtrack

Preorders are available on the PS Store and Xbox Store, though we’re still waiting for it to be listed on the Switch eShop. Fanatical is offering the lowest price of the bunch--so if you have the option to play on PC, this is the best way to save some cash.

If you're looking for more PC game deals, be sure to check out the slew of new bundle deals that launched as part of Fanatical's Bundlefest 2025 week. Five new bundles are available, each focused on specific genres like simulation games, themes like anime-inspired games or special editions, or game studios like Capcom. There's also the new Prestige Collection Bundlefest 2025 Edition, which packs heavy hitters like Tomb Raider 1-3 Remastered, Cryptmaster, Persona 4 Arena Ultimax, Super Monkey Ball Banana Mania, and more.

item.title: Avowed: Shatterscarp Cartographer Location For Mapping The Living Lands
item.content:encoded:
https://www.gamespot.com/articles/avowed-shatterscarp-cartographer-location-for-mapping-the-living-lands/1100-6529516/?ftag=CAD-01-10abi2f

GameSpot may receive revenue from affiliate and advertising partnerships for sharing this content and from purchases through links.

Shatterscarp is the third location you can visit in Avowed and as always, Sanza has a cartographer missing somewhere in the region. When you arrive in the main hub city of Thirdborn, a new Mapping the Living Lands quest will appear in your journal. If you read the journal entry, you'll see that Sanza's missing cartographer has disappeared near a lone spire by the sea.

While you can spend hours patrolling the coasts of Shatterscarp in Avowed, you can see exactly where the cartographer is located by reading the guide below.

Shatterscarp Cartographer location in Avowed

With Shatterscarp being directly on the ocean, there are plenty of places you can check for a "spire by the sea." The word spire is fairly vague, as it could be a physical building or something formed by nature.

Fortunately, you don't have to go too far from Thirdborn to find the missing cartographer in Shatterscarp. The cartographer is located to the east of Thirdborn, just above the large "Shatterscarp" text on your map. Go past Sailor's Rest until you reach a small island with a cylindrical boulder sticking out on top of it. Jump over the gap to reach the island and find the missing cartographer.

The missing cartographer's name is Wilfrith, and their body is lying against the spire. You can loot Wilfrith's body for some valuable loot as well as pick up Wilfrith's Map that's sitting right to the left of them. Once you have the map, this part of the quest is over, and you can now return to Sanza to tell him the bad news about another one of his cartographers.

You'll have to return to Sanza's Emporium in Paradis Hightowns in Dawnshore to complete the quest. You can open your map, press "The Living Lands" section at the top of the screen, and then select the region of Dawnshore from there. In Dawnshore, travel to the Administration District of Paradis, head into Paradis Hightowns via the grand staircase, and then visit Sanza's Emporium from there.

Talk to Sanza behind the counter, where you'll tell him the fate of Wilfrith. After speaking with Sanza, you've completed another Mapping the Living Lands quest in Avowed.

Obsidian is no stranger to crafting compelling RPGs. For more help on the team's latest effort, use our Avowed guides hub.
